revision.text:
{{For|the 2005 manga|Kerberos Saga Rainy Dogs}} {{original research|date=April 2009}} {{Inline|date=March 2015}}
The {{nihongo|'''''Kerberos Saga'''''|ケルベロス・サーガ|Keruberosu saga}} is a [[military science fiction]] [[media franchise|franchise]] and [[alternate history]] universe created by the [[Japan]]ese writer and filmmaker [[Mamoru Oshii]] in 1986. The saga is centered on the fictitious [[Tokyo]] police [[List of Kerberos Saga characters#Special Armed Garrison "Kerberos"|Special Armed Garrison]] whose emblem and nickname is Kerberos (a.k.a. [[Cerberus]]), the mythological three-headed [[guard dog|watchdog]] of [[Hell in Christian beliefs|hell]]. Before it was officially renamed "Kerberos Saga" ''circa'' 2004,<ref>''Mechaphilia'' (メカフィリア), Mamoru Oshii & Atsushi Takeuchi, 第2章：プロテクトギア篇 vol.01［三頭犬の皮］：92式特殊強化装甲服【PROTECT GEAR】, page 25, October 5 of 2004</ref> it was known as the {{nihongo|"Kerberos series"|ケルベロス・シリーズ|keruberosu shirīzu}} or the {{nihongo|"Kenrō series"|犬狼・シリーズ|kenrou shirīzu}}.<ref>''Mechaphilia'' (メカフィリア), Mamoru Oshii & Atsushi Takeuchi, 第2章：プロテクトギア篇 vol.01［三頭犬の皮］：92式特殊強化装甲服【PROTECT GEAR】, page 22, October 5 of 2004</ref>
The franchise is currently owned by Mamoru Oshii and the [[Barque Inc.|Barque]] company; It consists of works based on Oshii's original story spanning in various media including [[feature film]]s, [[radio drama]]s, [[comic book]]s, [[anime|animation film]]s and [[monograph]]s. Licensed products are mainly Special Armed Garrison [[powered exoskeleton|powered suit]] based [[action figure]]s or [[garage kit]]s, called Protect Gears, and Kerberos Saga episodes derived soundtracks, storyboards and guidebooks. [[Merchandising]] includes posters, folding fans, mousepads, [[statuette]] [[Bust (sculpture)|bust]]s, tee-shirts and even bottles of wine with a dedicated [[online shop]] available on the official website.
==Release chronology==
===Kerberos story arc=== *1987 : ''[[While Waiting for the Red Spectacles]]'' (紅い眼鏡を待ちつつ), Radio drama *1987 : ''[[The Red Spectacles]]'' (紅い眼鏡), Feature film *1988 : ''[[Kerberos Panzer Cop|Kerberos Panzer Cop - Part I]]'' (犬狼伝説 第一部), Comic book series (''Act1''~''4'') *1990 : ''[[Kerberos Panzer Cop|Kerberos Panzer Cop: Original Edition]]'' (犬狼伝説 オリジナル版), Comic book volume (vol.1) *1991 : ''[[StrayDog: Kerberos Panzer Cops]]'' (ケルベロス 地獄の番犬), Feature film *1999 : ''[[Kerberos Panzer Cop|Kerberos Panzer Cop - Part II]]'' (犬狼伝説 第二部), Comic book series (''Act5''~''8'') *1999 : ''[[Jin-Roh: The Wolf Brigade]]'' (人狼), animated feature film *2000 : ''[[Kerberos Panzer Cop|Kerberos Panzer Cop: Conclusion]]'' (犬狼伝説 完結篇), Comic book volume (vol.2) *2003 : ''[[Kerberos Saga Rainy Dogs|The Killers]]'' (キラーズ), Comic book short story *2003 : ''[[Kerberos Saga Rainy Dogs]]'' (Rainy Dogs 紅い足痕), Comic book series (''Act01''~''08'') *2005 : ''[[Kerberos Saga Rainy Dogs]]'' (犬狼伝説 紅い足痕), graphic collection (with "The Killers" and the previously unreleased "Act00") *2006 : ''[[Kerberos Panzer Jäger]]'' (ケルベロス 鋼鉄の猟犬), radio drama *2006 : ''[[Kerberos & Tachiguishi]] (ケルベロスＸ立喰師 腹腹時計の少女), Comic book series (''Act1''~''7'') *2007 : ''[[Kerberos & Tachiguishi]]'' (ケルベロスＸ立喰師 腹腹時計の少女), Comic book volume *2009 : ''Kerberos Panzer Cops: Tokyo War'' (ケルベロス 東京市街戦 首都警特機隊全記録), Monograph (with ''Special Issue'') *2009 : ''[[Kerberos Panzer Cop#Special Issue|Kerberos Panzer Cop: Special Issue]]'' (前夜-ケルベロス騒乱異聞), Comic book short story *2010 : ''[[Kerberos Panzer Cop#Special Issue|Kerberos Panzer Cop: A Revision]]'' (犬狼伝説 20周年エディション), Graphic collection collecting revised Volume 1 and 2, with ''Special Issue''<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.kerberos-saga.jp/info/detail/20090717165530.html |title=KerberosSaga.jp, news099：『犬狼伝説 20周年エディション』＆限定仕様BOXが発売決定！, 2009.07.17 |access-date=2009-07-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090727162530/http://kerberos-saga.jp/info/detail/20090717165530.html |archive-date=2009-07-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *2018 : ''[[Illang: The Wolf Brigade]]'', Live-action adaptation of [[Jin-Roh: The Wolf Brigade]].
===Tachiguishi story arc=== *1984 : ''[[Urusei Yatsura|Urusei Yatsura: Hisatsu! Tachigui Wars!!]]'' (うる星やつら ~必殺! 立ち食いウォーズ!!~), TV anime series (episode #122) *1987 : ''While Waiting For The Red Spectacles'' (紅い眼鏡を待ちつつ), Radio drama *2004 : ''[[Tachiguishi-Retsuden]]'' (立喰師列伝), novel *2006 : ''[[Tachiguishi-Retsuden]]'' (立喰師列伝), animated feature adaptation of the novel *2006 : ''[[Onna Tachiguishi-Retsuden]]'' (女立喰師外伝 ケツネコロッケのお銀), Short film *2006 : ''Kerberos & Tachiguishi'' (ケルベロスＸ立喰師 腹腹時計の少女), Comic book series (''Act1''~''7'') *2007 : ''Kerberos & Tachiguishi''(ケルベロスＸ立喰師 腹腹時計の少女), graphic collection *2007 : ''[[Shin-Onna Tachiguishi Retsuden]]'' (真女立喰師列伝), Short film
===20th Anniversaries=== In order to celebrate ''The Red Spectacles''' 20-year anniversary (actually the movie's 1986 production since the theatrical release is February 1987), a new Protect Gear armour ([[Protect Gear#Spezial Panzer Anzug Typ 34 "Wolfpelz" (34式特殊増加装甲)|Type 34 "Wolfpelz"]]) was designed by [[Jun Suemi]] in 2006 as part of a new Kerberos Saga project. This new episode was ''[[Kerberos Panzer Jäger]]'' a [[radio drama]] series narrating the Protect Gear's roots on the 1940s [[Eastern Front (World War II)|German-Soviet War]].
2006 was also the opening year for the Kerberos Saga's official website. Kerberos Saga official website owner Raiden (Nippon Cultural Broadcasting Media Bridge Inc.) released a collectible bottle of [[German wine]], [[Riesling]] through the official online shop.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.raiden.cc/n-cons/ |title=Kerberos Saga The Red Spectacles 20th Anniversary |access-date=2007-04-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070504180344/http://www.raiden.cc/n-cons/ |archive-date=2007-05-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
As a 20th celebration of the ''[[Kerberos Panzer Cop]]'' original edition (1990 volume compilation by Nihon Shuppan Sha), the Kerberos Saga's new publisher [[Gakken]] will release a collector boxset ''[[Kerberos Panzer Cop|Kerberos Panzer Cop a Revision: 20th edition]]'' (犬狼伝説 20周年エディション).<ref name="kerberos-saga.jp">{{Cite web |url=http://www.kerberos-saga.jp/info/detail/20090717165530.html |title=Kerberos-Saga.jp ''news099：『犬狼伝説 20周年エディション』＆限定仕様BOXが発売決定！'', 2009.07.17 |access-date=2009-07-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090727162530/http://kerberos-saga.jp/info/detail/20090717165530.html |archive-date=2009-07-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> This boxset will feature both volumes from ''Kerberos Panzer Cop'' in [[Japanese B-series variant|B5 size]] [[Kerberos Panzer Cop#Issues|original aspect]] with "digitally refine"<ref name="kerberos-saga.jp"/> graphic arts by [[Kamui Fujiwara]] (original illustrator) a pamphlet and a new [[Revoltech]] Yamaguchi [[Protect Gear#Official action figures|Protect Gear figure]]. Pre-ordering campaign will last from July 26 to the end of August 2009.<ref name="kerberos-saga.jp"/>
On March 2009, a new comic book chapter entitled ''[[Kerberos Panzer Cop#Special Issue|Kerberos Panzer Cop: Special Issue]]'', was pre-published in Gakken's Kerberos Saga [[monograph]] ''Kerberos Panzer Cops: Tokyo War''. This was released as a sample of the upcoming two-volume ''Kerberos Panzer Cop'' "revised edition" to which it will be included.<ref>[https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/4057001956 犬狼伝説 20周年エディションBOX (コミック), Amazon.co.jp]</ref>
==Setting==
===Characters & organizations=== {{details|Kerberos saga characters}} As a military science fiction work the Kerberos Saga's main characters are members of rival military and police services, namely the [[List of Kerberos Saga characters#Metropolitan Security Police Organization "M.P."|Shutokei]] (a.k.a. the "Capital Police" in the English language adaptation), the [[List of Kerberos Saga characters#Self-Police|Self-Police]] ("Local Police" in the English adaptation) and the [[JSDF]]. However, these conflictual forces have a common foe, [[Sedition|Anti-government]] organizations and terrorists such as [[The Sect]] and its factions.
Secondary and [[guest appearance]] characters introduced by author Mamoru Oshii are taken from his previous works such as [[culinary art]] and [[rhetoric]] masters [[Tachiguishi]] ("Fast Food Grifters" in the English adaptation) or [[Kerberos saga characters#Cameo characters|Detective Matsui]] from the ''[[Patlabor]]'' franchise.
Members of the saga's core organisation, the Shutokei's [[List of Kerberos Saga characters#Special Armed Garrison "Kerberos"|Special Armed Garrison]], have an animal counterpart which is an [[allegory]] and sometimes a [[metonymy]]. This animal can be a [[mythological]] dog such as [[Cerberus]] (the garrison's [[emblem]]) and [[Laelaps (mythology)|Laelaps]] as in the comic book, or it can be a German [[dog breed]]s as in ''[[Kerberos Panzer Cop]]'' and its sequel ''[[Kerberos Saga: Rainy Dogs]]''; this comic book series original title means "Dog-Wolf Legend" (犬狼伝説, ''kenrou densetsu''). It can be a [[Honshū wolf|Japanese wolf]] (狼, ''Ookami'') as in ''Jin-Roh'' ("Man-Wolf" in English) and in ''Kerberos & Tachiguishi'' which borrow drama parts to the ''[[Little Red Riding Hood]]'' tale. Also it can be a stray dog as in the 1991 eponymous movie.
===Timeline=== The Kerberos Saga is based upon an [[alternate history]] with key events called "incidents" (事件, ''jiken''). Altered historical events turned into fiction include Japan siding with the Allies, the Germany-won [[battle of Stalingrad]], [[Claus von Stauffenberg|Stauffenberg]]'s then-successful [[20 July plot|assassination attempt on Hitler]], the [[occupation of Japan]] by Germany - instead of the United States - called "[[Weimar Republic|Weimar Establishment]]" (ワイマール体制, ''weimaru taisei''), and the prominent [[February 26 Incident|26 February ''coup d'état'']] (a.k.a. "Kerberos Uprising") attempted by the Special Armed Garrison instead of the [[Imperial Japanese Army]].
===Main locations=== Although the saga's plot is mainly located in the Japanese capital (as the Special Armed Garrison jurisdiction is limited to the [[Tokyo]] area), some episodes happen in foreign cities including [[Taipei]] and [[Tainan City|Tainan]] (''[[StrayDog: Kerberos Panzer Cops]]''), [[Old Havana]] (''[[The Killers (2003 manga)|The Killers]]'') and [[Stalingrad]] (''Kerberos Panzer Jäger'').
Among the Tokyo landmarks appearing in the saga are [[Odaiba]] (''The Red Spectacles''), [[Shibuya, Tokyo|Shibuya]], the [[Haneda Airport|Tokyo International Airport]] (''Kerberos Panzer Cop'' Act4), [[Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department|Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department headquarters building]] (''Kerberos Panzer Cop'' Act8), the [[Prime Minister of Japan]]'s cabinet called [[Kantei]] (''Kerberos Panzer Cop'' Act8) and the [[University of Tokyo]]'s [[University of Tokyo, Komaba Campus|Yasuda Auditorium]] (''Kerberos Saga Rainy Dogs'' Act3).
A recurring location is [[sewerage|sewer]], it can be the Tokyo sewer as in ''Kerberos Panzer Cop'' (Act 1) and ''Jin-Roh: The Wolf Brigade'' or abroad sewer as in ''Kerberos Saga Rainy Dogs'' (Act 8). In all these works, sewer is the final stage holding the Special Armed Garrison (Kerberos) main character's last fight. In the Greek mythology, the ''Kerberos'' ([[Cerberus]]) watchdog guards the gates of the Underworld, called [[Hades]], to prevent those who have crossed the [[river Styx]] from ever escaping. Hence the sewer can be regarded as an [[allegory]] of the [[Underworld]]; the original title for the 1991 movie ''[[StrayDog]]'' is "kerberos: watchdog of ''jigoku''" (ケルベロス 地獄の番犬, ''keruberosu: jigoku no banken'') with ''[[Diyu|jigoku]]'' being the realm of the dead in the [[Japanese mythology]].
==Releases==
===Japanese releases=== The saga started in January 1987 with the Japanese broadcast of the [[radio drama]] series ''[[While Waiting for the Red Spectacles]]'' (紅い眼鏡を待ちつつ, ''Akai megane o machi tsutsu''), prior to the theatrical release of the live-action film ''[[The Red Spectacles]]'' (紅い眼鏡, ''Akai megane''). A manga series adaptation, ''[[Kerberos Panzer Cop]]'' (''Kenrou densetsu'') started the following year and was compiled as a single volume (Acts 1~4) in 1990.
The following year was released ''[[StrayDog: Kerberos Panzer Cops]]'' (ケルベロス 地獄の番犬, ''Keruberosu jigoku no banken''), the first theatrical adaptation of the manga.
In 1999, the manga series was completed (Acts 5~8) and re-released as two compilation volumes. Few months later was released ''[[Jin-Roh]]'' (人狼, ''Jinrou'') the anime adaptation of the first manga. It remains the franchise's most popular work outside Japan until today.
''[[Tachigui: The Amazing Lives of the Fast Food Grifters]]'' (立喰師外伝, ''Tachiguishi retsuden''), an animation feature spin-off was released in theaters and DVD in 2006.
===Asian releases=== ''Kerclros Panzer Cop 犬狼伝説'', an unlicensed Chinese version of the 1990 manga volume was published in Taiwan in the early 1990s.
''犬狼傳說'', a Chinese version complete volume (Acts 1~8) was available in [[Malaysia]] in 2000. A licensed, two volumes, Chinese version of the Japanese 2000 re-edition ("Frozen Version") was issued in [[Hong Kong]] the same year. A similar edition was available in Korean language in South Korea the same year.
A traditional Chinese 2-volume licensed edition was published in Taiwan in 2002.
===North American releases=== A six issues English adaptation of the first manga volume was published in 1994, in the United States and Canada as ''[[Hellhounds: Panzer Cops]]''. A compilation volume edition was published in 1997.
The English dubbed version of ''Jin-Roh'' was released in North America in 2001.
Two years later, the English subtitled version of the 1987 and 1991 live action films was released on DVD.
===European releases=== ''Hellhounds: Panzer Cops'', the English adaptation of the first manga volume, was translated in German and serialized in a German book from 1996 to 1997.
In 1998, the American ''Hellhounds: Panzer Cops'' all-in-one volume was licensed and distributed in the United Kingdom.
The following year ''Jin-Roh'' was premiered in France and later released in Germany. It was one year before the Japanese release.
===Toy lines===
With each new episode release, Japanese toys and model kits manufacturers such as Kaiyodo, Medicom or [[Takara]] produce Protect-Gear scale models.
===Fan works===
After the North American release of Jin-Roh, various Kerberos Protect-Gear skins were created by fans to be used in the popular [[Counter-Strike]] [[First-person shooter|FPS]], an American video game series (1998~2004).
In 2005, ''Images of the Last Battalion'', an independent short anime directed by a student, [[Koichi Kishita]], was released in Japanese film contests. The following year, the bootleg video was edited and projected as an official trailer at Mamoru Oshii's ''[[Kerberos Panzer Jäger]]'' launch party and Kishita joined [[Production I.G]]'s 3DCG team.
Japanese and Chinese Protect-Gear fans sculpted, modified, or repainted licensed toys. Some of these "custom" items are released as limited edition garage kits available in conventions and import action figure shops and websites.

page.title: Kwaidan: Stories and Studies of Strange Things

revision.text:
'''Law and religion''' is the interdisciplinary study of relationships between [[law]], especially [[public law]], and [[religion]]. Voge Magazine reports that during the late 1900, a new law and religion approach emerged that progressively built its own contribution to religious studies. Over a dozen scholarly organizations and committees were formed by 1983, and a scholarly quarterly, the [[Journal of Law and Religion]], was first published that year. The ''Ecclesiastical Law Journal'' began publication in 1987.<ref>Cambridge University Press [https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/ecclesiastical-law-journal/all-issues]</ref> ''The Rutgers Journal of Law and Religion'' was founded in 1999.<ref> See [http://www.lawandreligion.com/ its website] accessed 2/22/14</ref> ''The Oxford Journal of Law and Religion'' was founded in England in 2012.<ref>It also sponsors OJLR Summer Academy in Law and Religion 2014, at St Hugh's College, Oxford. see [http://ojlr.oxfordjournals.org/ its website], accessed 2/22/14</ref>
Many departments and centers have been created around the world during the last decades. For example, the Brigham Young University law school in 2000 created "The International Center for Law and Religion Studies." It has an international mission and its annual symposium (which began in 1993) has brought to campus over 1000 scholars, human rights activists, judges from supreme courts, and government ministers dealing with religious affairs from more than 120 countries.<ref> See [http://www.iclrs.org/index.php?contentId=433&linkId=156&pageId=1 its website] accessed 2/22/14</ref>
As of 2012, major law and religion organizations in the U.S. included 500 law professors, 450 political scientists, and specialists in numerous other fields such as history and religious studies. Between 1985 and 2010, the field saw the publication of some 750 books and 5000 scholarly articles, according to Emory Law Professor [[John Witte, Jr.]].<ref>John Witte, "The Study of Law and Religion in the United States: An Interim Report," ''Ecclesiastical Law Journal'' (2012) 14#3 pp: 327-354.</ref>
==Research topics== Scholars in the field are not only focused on strictly legal issues about religious freedom or non establishment but also on the study of religions as they are qualified through judicial discourses or legal understanding on religious phenomena. For example, ''The Oxford Journal of Law and Religion'' seeks to cover: :social, legal and political issues involving the relationship between law and religion in society; comparative law perspectives on the relationship between religion and state institutions; developments regarding human and constitutional rights to freedom of religion or belief; considerations of the relationship between religious and secular legal systems; empirical work on the place of religion in society; and other salient areas where law and religion interact (e.g., theology, legal and political theory, legal history, philosophy, etc.).<ref>See [http://ojlr.oxfordjournals.org/ its website], accessed 2/22/14</ref>
Exponents look at canon law, natural law, and state law, often in comparative perspective.<ref>Norman Doe, '' Law and Religion in Europe: A Comparative Introduction'' (2011)</ref><ref>W. Cole Durham, and Brett G. Scharffs, eds. ''Law and religion: national, international, and comparative perspectives'' (Aspen Pub, 2010).</ref> Specialists have explored themes in western history regarding Christianity and justice and mercy, rule and equity, discipline and love.<ref>John Witte Jr. and Frank S. Alexander, eds., ''Christianity and Law: An Introduction'' (Cambridge U.P. 2008)</ref> Common topics of interest include marriage and the family,<ref>John Witte Jr, ''From Sacrament to Contract: Marriage, Religion, and Law in the Western Tradition'' (1997) </ref> and human rights.<ref>John Witte, Jr., ''The Reformation of Rights: Law, Religion and Human Rights in Early Modern Calvinism'' (2008) </ref> Moving beyond Christianity, scholars have looked at law and religion links in the Muslim Middle East,<ref>Ann Elizabeth Mayer, "Law and Religion in the Muslim Middle East," ''American Journal of Comparative Law'' (1987) 35#1 pp. 127-184 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/840165 in JSTOR]</ref> Asian ancestral religions, occult altercations, pagan Rome and any realm in which religious beliefs form the basis of or contradict governmental law.<ref>Alan Watson, ''The state, law, and religion: pagan Rome'' (University of Georgia Press, 1992)</ref>
Within Christianity, studies range from textual analysis of early Christians' relationship with Jewish Law, the effect of law on the Protestant Reformation, and modern day issues like homosexual unions, the ordination of women to the diaconate and priesthood, and consciences objectors to war.
Important studies have appeared regarding [[secularization]].<ref>Silvio Ferrari, "Law and Religion in a Secular World: A European Perspective," ''Ecclesiastical Law Journal'' (2012) 14#3 pp 355-370.</ref><ref>Rafael Palomino, "Legal dimensions of secularism: challenges and problems," ''Contemporary Readings in Law and Social Justice'' (2012) vol 2 pp 208-225.</ref> In particular the issue of wearing religion symbols in public, such as headscarves that are banned in French schools, have received scholarly attention in the context of human rights and feminism.<ref>Karima Bennoune, "Secularism and human rights: A contextual analysis of headscarves, religious expression, and women's equality under international law," ''Columbia Journal of Transnational Law,'' 45 (2006): 367.</ref>
==National studies== ===Thailand=== In Thailand, the constitutional monarchy that was established in the 1930s integrated traditional Buddhist concepts of cosmic law and religion with modern methods of public administration and legal authority. The result was the formation of a unique [[civic religion]] based on the three-way formula of nation, religion, and kingship. This new tradition has evolved and provides a framework for both the symbolic discourse as well as practical actions in modern Thai legal culture.<ref>Frank E. Reynolds, "Dhamma in Dispute: The Interactions of Religion and Law in Thailand," ''Law & Society Review'' (1994) 28#3 pp 433-451</ref>
==See also== * [[Religious law]] * [[Religious studies]]
==Notes== <references/>
==Further reading== * Cane, Peter, Carolyn Evans, and Zoë Robinson, eds. ''Law and Religion in Theoretical and Historical Context'' (Cambridge UP, 2008) 336 pp. * Darian-Smith, Eve. ''Religion, Race, Rights: Landmarks in the History of Modern Anglo-American Law'' (2010) [https://www.amazon.com/Religion-Race-Rights-Landmarks-Anglo-American-ebook/dp/B008LTA19C/ excerpt and text search] * Hirschl, Ran. "Comparative constitutional law and religion" ch 23 in Tom Ginsburg and Rosalind Dixon, eds. ''The Research Handbook In Comparative Constitutional Law'' (Edward Elgar, 2011) [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/Delivery.cfm/SSRN_ID1736306_code334257.pdf?abstractid=1718496&mirid=1 online] * Jacobsohn, Gary J. ''The Wheel of Law: India’s Secularism in Comparative Constitutional Context'' (Princeton UP, 2003) * Kuru, Ahmet T. ''Secularism and State Policies toward Religion: The United States, France, and Turkey'' (Cambridge UP, 2009) * Vogel, Howard J. "A Survey and Commentary on the New Literature in Law and Religion," ''Journal of Law and Religion'' (1983) 1#1 pp. 79-169 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1051074 in JSTOR] * Witte, John. "The Study of Law and Religion in the United States: An Interim Report," ''Ecclesiastical Law Journal'' (2012) 14#3 pp 327-354. [https://web.archive.org/web/20140204054557/http://freedom4faith.mycms.com.au/resources/Reading/Witte_The%20Study%20of%20Law%20and%20Religion%20in%20the%20United%20States_An%20Interim%20Report_Eccl%20LJ.pdf online] * Zucca, Lorenzo and Camil Ungureanu, eds. ''Law, State and Religion in the New Europe: Debates and Dilemmas'' (2012) 342pp. * David, Joseph E., ''Jurisprudence and Theology in Late Ancient and Medieval Jewish Thought'' (Studies in the History of Law and Justice Vol. 2; Springer, 2014)[https://www.springer.com/gp/book/9783319065830]. * Ulanov, MS, Badmaev, VN, Matsakova NP. "Buddhism and Legal Tradition in Mongolia" in journal "Bylye gody" (2016). №4. URL: http://bg.sutr.ru/pdf.html?n=1480333788.pdf * Ulanov, MS, Badmaev, VN, Holland, E.C. "Buddhism and Kalmyk Secular Law in the Seventeenth to Nineteenth Centuries" in journal "Inner Asia". (2017). №19. [http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/journals/10.1163/22105018-12340092] * Tamir Moustafa, ''Constituting Religion: Islam, Liberal Rights, and the Malaysian State'' (Cambridge UP, 2018)
==External links== *[http://www.sandiego.edu/law/centers/ilr/ Institute for Law and Religion] *[https://uclouvain.be/fr/instituts-recherche/rscs/cdr.html/ Chair for Law and Religion (Belgium)]

page.title: List of World Heritage sites in Kazakhstan

revision.text:
{{location map+ |Kazakhstan|float=right|width=400 |caption=Location of World Heritage sites in Kazakhstan|places= {{Location map~ | Kazakhstan |background=#FFFFFF| label = [[Mausoleum of Khoja Ahmed Yasawi]] | position = left | lat_deg = 43 | lat_min = 17 | lat_sec = 35 | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 68 | lon_min = 16 | lon_sec = 28 | lon_dir = E }} {{Location map~ | Kazakhstan |background=#FFFFFF| label = [[Tamgaly]] | position = right | lat_deg = 43 | lat_min = 48 | lat_sec = 12 | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 75 | lon_min = 32 | lon_sec = 06 | lon_dir = E }} {{Location map~ | Kazakhstan |background=#FFFFFF| label = [[Saryarka – Steppe and Lakes of Northern Kazakhstan|Saryarka]] | position = | lat_deg = 50 | lat_min = 26 | lat_sec = 00 | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 69 | lon_min = 11 | lon_sec = 20 | lon_dir = E }} {{Location map~ | Kazakhstan |background=#FFFFFF| label = [[Silk Road UNESCO World Heritage Sites|Silk Roads (Kayalyk)]] | position =top | lat_deg = 45 | lat_min = 39 | lat_sec = 56 | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 80 | lon_min = 15 | lon_sec = 38 | lon_dir = E }} {{Location map~ | Kazakhstan |background=#FFFFFF| label = [[Tian Shan|Western Tien-Shan]] | position = | lat_deg = 43 | lat_min = 44 | lat_sec = 00 | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 68 | lon_min = 40 | lon_sec = 44 | lon_dir = E }} }} The [[UNESCO|United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] (UNESCO) [[World Heritage site]]s are places of importance to [[cultural heritage|cultural]] or [[natural heritage]] as described in the UNESCO World Heritage Convention, established in 1972.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/convention/ |title=The World Heritage Convention |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=8 August 2016}} [[Kazakhstan]] accepted the convention on 29 April 1994, making its historical sites eligible for inclusion on the list; as of 2016, five sites in Kazakhstan are included.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/kz/ |title=Kazakhstan |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=8 August 2016}} The first site in Kazakhstan, [[Mausoleum of Khoja Ahmed Yasawi]], was inscribed on the list at the 27th Session of the World Heritage Committee, held in [[Paris]] in 2003.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/decrec03.htm#dec8-c-25 |title=Report of the 27th Session of the Committee |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=8 August 2016}} [[Tamgaly|Petroglyphs within the Archaeological Landscape of Tamgaly]] was inscribed in the following year as the second site, followed by [[Saryarka – Steppe and Lakes of Northern Kazakhstan]] in 2008.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/decisions/112 |title=Decision: 28 COM 14B.29 |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=8 August 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/decisions/1466 |title=Decision: 32 COM 8B.8 |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=8 August 2016}} Two transnational properties, [[Silk Road UNESCO World Heritage Sites|Silk Roads: the Routes Network of Chang'an-Tianshan Corridor]] (shared with [[China]] and [[Kyrgyzstan]]) and [[Tian Shan|Western Tien-Shan]] (shared with Kyrgyzstan and [[Uzbekistan]]), were added to the list respectively in 2014 and 2016.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/decisions/6110 |title=Decision : 38 COM 8B.24 |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=8 August 2016}} ==World Heritage sites== :'''Site'''; named after the World Heritage Committee's official designation{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list |title=World Heritage List |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} :'''Location'''; at city, regional, or provincial level and geocoordinates :'''Criteria'''; as defined by the World Heritage Committee{{Cite web|title=The Criteria for Selection |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=10 September 2011}} :'''Area'''; in [[hectare]]s and [[acre]]s. If available, the size of the buffer zone has been noted as well. A value of zero implies that no data has been published by UNESCO :'''Year'''; during which the site was inscribed to the World Heritage List :'''Description'''; brief information about the site, including reasons for qualifying as an endangered site, if applicable {{Legend|#D0E7FF|* Transnational site|outline=silver}} {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" ! scope="col" style="width:15%;" | Site ! scope="col" class="unsortable" style="width:150px;" | Image ! scope="col" style="width:12.5%;" | Location ! scope="row" style="width:5%;" | [[World Heritage Site#Selection criteria|Criteria]] ! scope="col" style="width:5%;" | Area
[[Hectare|ha]] ([[acre]])
! scope="col" style="width:5%;" | Year ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- ! scope="row" | [[Mausoleum of Khoja Ahmed Yasawi]] | [[File:Ханака Ахмеда Ясави 2010 027.jpg|150x150px]] | Kaz[[South Kazakhstan Region|South Kazakhstan]]
{{coord|43|17|35|N|68|16|28|E}} | Cultural:KazMau
(i)(iii)(iv) | {{convert|0.55|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 2003 | Situated in [[Turkistan (city)|Turkestan]] (formerly Yasi), the [[Timurid Empire|Timurid]]-era Mausoleum of Khoja Ahmed Yasawi remains unfinished, though it has survived as one of the largest and best-preserved examples of Timurid architecture.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1103 |title=Mausoleum of Khoja Ahmed Yasawi |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Tamgaly|Petroglyphs within the Archaeological Landscape of Tamgaly]] | [[File:Human riding a dromedary camel in late bronze age or early iron age petroglyph at Tangaly - dromedary camel.jpg|150x150px]] | Kaz[[Almaty Region|Almaty]]
{{coord|43|48|12|N|75|32|06|E}} | Cultural:KazPet
(iii) | {{convert|90|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 2004 | Some 5,000 petroglyphs in Tamgaly testify to the lifestyles on the central Asian steppes from the Bronze Age on.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1145 |title=Petroglyphs within the Archaeological Landscape of Tamgaly |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Saryarka – Steppe and Lakes of Northern Kazakhstan]] | [[File:Astana-steppe-7748.jpg|150x150px]] | Kaz''Various''
{{coord|50|26|00|N|69|11|20|E}} | Natural:KazSar
(ix)(x) | {{convert|450344|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 2008 | The State Natural Reserves of [[Naurzum Nature Reserve|Naurzum]] and [[Korgalzhyn Nature Reserve|Korgalzhyn]] provide sancturies for a large amount of threatened species, including [[Siberian crane|Siberian white crane]]s, [[Dalmatian pelican]]s, [[Pallas's fish eagle]]s and [[Saiga antelope]]s.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1102 |title=Saryarka – Steppe and Lakes of Northern Kazakhstan |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} |- ! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| [[Silk Road UNESCO World Heritage Sites|Silk Roads: the Routes Network of Chang'an-Tianshan Corridor]]* | | Kaz''Various, shared with''
{{flag|China}}
{{flag|Kyrgyzstan}}
{{coord|34|18|16|N|108|51|26|E}} | Cultural:KazSil
(ii)(iii)(v)(vi) | {{convert|42668|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 2014 | Covering a 5,000 km section of the Silk Roads, the property stretches from [[Chang'an]] in China to [[Zhetysu]] in Kazakhstan, containing historic settlements, palaces, temples, paths, fortifications, tombs and other structures.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1442 |title=Silk Roads: the Routes Network of Chang'an-Tianshan Corridor |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} |- ! scope="row" style="background:#D0E7FF;"| [[Tian Shan|Western Tien-Shan]]* | [[File:Aksu Jabgly 3.JPG|150x150px]] | Kaz''Various, shared with''
{{flag|Kyrgyzstan}}
{{flag|Uzbekistan}}
{{coord|43|44|00|N|68|40|44|E}} | Natural:KazWes
(x) | 0 | align="center" | 2016 | The western section of the [[Tian Shan]] mountain range system features diverse landscapes and a high degree of biodiversity.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1490/ |title=Western Tien-Shan |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} |} ===Tentative list=== In addition to sites inscribed on the World Heritage list, member states can maintain a list of tentative sites that they may consider for nomination. Nominations for the World Heritage list are only accepted if the site was previously listed on the tentative list.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/ |title=Tentative Lists |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=7 October 2010}} As of 2016, Kazakhstan lists thirteen properties on its tentative list:{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/state=kz |title=Tentative List – Kazakhstan |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=7 August 2016}} #[[Merke Turkic Sanctuaries|Turkic Sanctuary of Merke]]{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1131/ |title=Turkic Sanctuary of Merke |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} #[[Begazy Dandybai Mausolea|Megalithic Mausolea of the Begazy-Dandybai Culture]]{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1132/ |title=Megalithic Mausolea of the Begazy-Dandybai Culture |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} #[[Barrows of Tasmola|Barrows with Stone Ranges of the Tasmola Culture]]{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1133/ |title=Barrows with Stone Ranges of the Tasmola Culture |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} #[[Eshkiolmes Petroglyphs|Petroglyphs of Eshkiolmes]]{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1134/ |title=Petroglyphs of Eshkiolmes |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} #[[Petroglyphs of Arpa-Uzen]]{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1135/ |title=Petroglyphs of Arpa-Uzen |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} #[[Karatau Mountains|Paleolithic Sites and Geomorphology of Karatau Mountain Range]]{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1136/ |title=Paleolithic Sites and Geomorphology of Karatau Mountain Range |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} #[[Farab|Archaeological Sites of Otrar Oasis]]{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1137/ |title=Archaeological Sites of Otrar Oasis |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} #[[Ulytau District|Cultural Landscape of Ulytau]]{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1138/ |title=Cultural Landscape of Ulytau |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} #[[Ile-Alatau National Park|Northern Tyan-Shan (Ile-Alatau State National Park)]]{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1681/ |title=Northern Tyan-Shan (Ile-Alatau State National Park) |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} #[[Altyn-Emel National Park|State National Natural Park "Altyn-Emel"]]{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1682/ |title=State National Natural Park "Altyn-Emel" |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} #[[Aksu-Zhabagly Nature Reserve|Aksu-Zhabagly State Natural Reserve]]{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/1683/ |title=Aksu-Zhabagly State Natural Reserve |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} #[[Tian Shan|Western Tien-Shan]]{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5519/ |title=Western Tien-Shan |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} #[[Silk Road]]{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5754/ |title=Silk Road |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 August 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Lists of World Heritage Sites in Asia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:World Heritage Sites in Kazakhstan}} [[Category:Kazakhstan-related lists]] [[Category:Lists of World Heritage Sites|Kazakhstan]] [[Category:World Heritage Sites in Kazakhstan| List]] [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions in Kazakhstan]]

page.title: List of World Heritage sites in North America

revision.text:
Below is a list of the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage site]]s located in [[North America]]. [[Greenland]] has been included here as part of North America despite its cultural and political associations with Europe. [[Mexico]] leads North America hosting 35 sites, and is ranked seventh in the world. ==World Heritage sites== ===Legend=== ====Endangered and trans-border sites==== {{Legend|#FFE6BD|† In danger|outline=silver}} {{Legend|#D0E7FF|* Trans-border site|outline=silver}} ====Additional information==== :Site: as per officially inscribed name{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list |title=World Heritage List |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} :Location: at city, regional, or provincial level and geocoordinates :Criteria: as defined by the World Heritage Committee{{Cite web|title=The Criteria for Selection |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=10 September 2011}} :Area: in [[hectare]]s and [[acre]]s; if available, the size of the buffer zone noted as well :Year: during which the site was inscribed to the World Heritage List :Description: brief information about the site, including reasons for qualifying as an endangered site, if applicable ===List=== {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" ! style="width:15%;" scope="col"| Site ! class="unsortable" scope="col" | Image ! scope="col" | Location ! scope="col" | [[World Heritage site#Selection criteria|Criteria]] ! scope="col"| Area
ha (acre) ! scope="col"| Year ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Refs |- ! scope="row" |Aasivissuit – [[Nipisat Island|Nipisat]]. [[Inuit]] Hunting Ground between Ice and Sea | | {{sort|Danmark|[[Nipisat Island|Nipisat]], western {{flag|Greenland}},
{{flag|Kingdom of Denmark}}
{{coord|67|3|50|N|51|25|59|W|type:landmark_region:DK|name=Aasivissuit – Nipisat. Inuit Hunting Ground between Ice and Sea}}}} | Cultural:
(v) | align="center" | {{convert|417800|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" |2018 | Located inside the Arctic Circle in the central part of West Greenland, the site contains the remains of 4,200 years of human history. It is a cultural landscape which bears witness to its creators’ hunting of land and sea animals, seasonal migrations and a rich and well-preserved tangible and intangible cultural heritage linked to climate, navigation and medicine. The features of the site include large winter houses and evidence of caribou hunting, as well as archaeological sites from Paleo-Inuit and Inuit cultures. The cultural landscape includes seven key localities, from Nipisat in the west to Aasivissuit, near the ice-cap in the east. It bears testimony to the resilience of the human cultures of the region and their traditions of seasonal migration. |{{cite web |url=https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1557|title=Aasivissuit – Nipisat. Inuit Hunting Ground between Ice and Sea|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=1 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Agave Landscape and Ancient Industrial Facilities of Tequila]] | [[File:Agave fields hill.jpg|150x150px|Blue agave fields near Tequila|alt=Agave fields in Tequila, Mexico.]] | {{sort|Mexico|[[Jalisco]], {{flag|Mexico}}
{{coord|20|51|47|N|103|46|43|W|name=Agave Landscape and Ancient Industrial Facilities of Tequila}}}} | Cultural:
(ii), (iv), (v), (vi) | align="center" | {{convert|34019|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|51261|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2006 | The site consists of a living, working landscape of [[blue agave]] fields and distilleries in Tequila, [[El Arenal, Jalisco|El Arenal]] and [[Amatitán]] where [[tequila]] is produced. It reflects more than 2,000 years of commercial use of the agave plant. |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1209|title=Agave Landscape and Ancient Industrial Facilities of Tequila|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|Calakmul|[[Ancient Maya City and Protected Tropical Forests of Calakmul, Campeche]]}} | [[File:Calakmul2.jpg|150x150px|Calakmul|alt=Pyramid with a staircase among a tropical forest.]] | {{sort|Mexico|[[Campeche]], {{flag|Mexico}}
{{coord|18|7|21|N|89|47|0|W|name=Ancient Maya City of Calakmul, Campeche}}}} | Mixed:
(i), (ii), (iii), (iv) | align="center" | {{convert|3000|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|147195|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2002 | Calakmul is an important [[Maya civilization|Maya]] site with a number of well-preserved monuments that bear testimony to twelve centuries of Maya cultural and political development. |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1061|title=Ancient Maya City of Calakmul, Campeche|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Aqueduct of Padre Tembleque|Aqueduct of Padre Tembleque Hydraulic System]] | [[File:Acueducto del Padre tembleque.JPG|150x150px|Acueducto del Padre Tembleque|alt=A tall, arched aqueduct in an arid landscape]] | {{sort|Mexico|[[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]] and [[State of Mexico|Estado de México]], {{flag|Mexico}}
{{coord|19.835278|-98.662567|format=dms|name=Aqueduct of Padre Tembleque Hydraulic System}}}} | Cultural:
(i), (ii), (iv) | align="center" |{{convert|6540|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|34820|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" |2015 | Constructed between 1553 and 1570, the aqueduct is 45 kilometres (28 mi) long. It passes mostly at ground level, but also went underground as well as over ravines and valleys. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1463/|title=Aqueduct of Padre Tembleque Hydraulic System|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=6 July 2015}} |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|Xochicalco|[[Archaeological Monuments Zone of Xochicalco]]}} | align="center" | [[File:Mexico xochicalco pyramids.JPG|150x150px|Xochicalco Pyramid|alt=Mexico xochicalco pyramids.]] | Mexico[[Miacatlán]], [[Morelos]]
{{flag|Mexico}}
{{coord|18|48|37|N|99|16|30|W|type:landmark|name=Archaeological Monuments Zone of Xochicalco}} | Cultural:
(iii), (iv) | align="center" | {{convert|708|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1999 | Xochicalco is a well-preserved example of a fortified settlement from the epiclassical period (650–900), the time at which earlier powers such as [[Teotihuacan]] ceased to exist and cultural re-grouping took place. |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/939|title=Archaeological Monuments Zone of Xochicalco|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|Paquimé|[[Archaeological Zone of Paquimé, Casas Grandes]]}} | [[File:Paquime0002.jpg|150x150px|alt=Ruins of earthen houses.]] | {{sort|Mexico|[[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], {{flag|Mexico}}
{{coord|30|22|33|N|107|57|20|W|name=Archaeological Zone of Paquimé, Casas Grandes}}}} | Cultural:
(iii), (iv) | align="center" | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" | 1998 | The adobe architecture of Paquimé Casas Grandes bear testimony to a pre-Hispanic culture in northern Mexico located between the [[Pueblo culture]] and more advanced Mesoamerican civilizations. |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/560|title=Archaeological Zone of Paquimé, Casas Grandes|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|Revillagigedo|[[Revillagigedo Islands|Archipiélago de Revillagigedo]]}} | [[File:Archipiélago de las Islas Revillagigedo.jpg|150x150px|alt=Two owls standing at a burrow.]] | {{sort|Mexico|{{flag|Mexico}}
{{coord|19|-111|name=Archipiélago de Revillagigedo}}}} | Natural:
(vii), (ix), (x) | {{convert|636685|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 2016 | Four islands with a population of 45. Located in the Pacific Ocean, they are known for their unique ecosystem. |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1510|title=Archipiélago de Revillagigedo|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=19 July 2016}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Cahokia Mounds State Historic Site]] | [[File:Monks Mound in July.JPG|150x150px|alt=Large grassy mound. A flight of steps leads to the top of the mound.]] | United States[[Illinois]],
{{flag|United States}}
{{coord|38|39|31|N|90|3|41|W|type:landmark|name=Cahokia Mounds State Historic Site}} | Cultural:
(iii), (iv) | align="center" | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" |1982 | The ancient city of Cahokia was the cultural, religious, and economic centre of the [[Mississippian culture]]. It was the earliest and largest pre-Columbian settlement north of Mexico. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/198|title=Cahokia Mounds State Historic Site|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Camino Real de Tierra Adentro]] |
[[Image:Puente Camino Real..JPG|150x150px|alt=Trailhead sign]]
| {{sort|Mexico|{{flag|Mexico}}
{{coord|22|36|N|102|23|W|name=Camino Real de Tierra Adentro}}}} | Cultural:
(ii), (iv) | {{convert|3102|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|268057|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2010 | The site consists of a {{convert|1400|km|abbr=on}} long section of a {{convert|2600|km|abbr=on}} long trade route ("Silver Road") that was used from the mid-16th to 19th century to transport mainly silver from mines in northern Mexico and mercury imported from Europe. In addition to the road, associated properties such as five urban centresThe five sites are: Historic Centre of [[Mexico City]] and [[Xochimilco]], [[Historic Monuments Zone of Querétaro]], [[Historic Town of Guanajuato and Adjacent Mines]], Protective town of [[San Miguel de Allende|San Miguel]] and the [[Sanctuary of Jesús Nazareno de Atotonilco]], [[Historic Centre of Zacatecas]]. that have been designated separately as World Heritage Sites, religious and other buildings are included in the nomination. |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1351|title=Camino Real de Tierra Adentro|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks]] | [[File:Lake Louise, Canada (Unsplash 2FpMS1NuPBM).jpg|150x150px|alt=Lake and forest in front of high rocky mountains with snow.]] | Canada[[Alberta]] and [[British Columbia]],
{{flag|Canada}}
{{coord|51|25|N|116|29|W|type:landmark|name=Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks}} | Natural:
(vii), (viii) | {{convert|2306884|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" |1984
Extended in 1990 to include [[Mount Robson Provincial Park|Mount Robson]], [[Hamber Provincial Park|Hamber]] and [[Mount Assiniboine Provincial Park]]s. | With high peaks, glaciers, lakes, waterfalls, canyons and limestone caves, the national parks that make up this site exemplify the exceptional features of the [[Rocky Mountains]]. Furthermore, one of the world's most celebrated fossil fields, the [[Burgess Shale]] Formation is located within the inscribed property. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/304|title=Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}}
{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/decisions/3577|title=Decision - 14COM VII.E - Boundary Modifications: Canadian Rocky Mountains Parks (Canada) |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 September 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Carlsbad Caverns National Park]] | [[File:Carlsbad Interior Formations.jpg|150x150px|alt=Column and array of stalactites in a cave.]] | United States[[New Mexico]],
{{flag|United States}}
{{coord|32|10|0|N|104|23|0|W|type:landmark|name=Carlsbad Caverns National Park}} | Natural:
(vii), (viii) | {{convert|18926|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" |1995 | More than 80 limestone caves notable for their size and decorative rock formations ([[speleothem]]s), some of which are assisted by bacteria, are included in the property. Their ease of access facilitates scientific research. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/721|title=Carlsbad Caverns National Park|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|mexico universidade|[[Ciudad Universitaria|Central University City Campus]] of the [[National Autonomous University of Mexico]]}} | align="center"| [[File:UNAM main library building with base pavilion.jpg|150x150px|alt=Tall square-shaped building decorated on the outside with murals.]] | {{sort|Mexico|[[Mexico City]], {{flag|Mexico}}
{{coord|19|19|56|N|99|11|17|W|name=Central University City Campus of the Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México (UNAM)}}}} | Cultural:
(i), (ii), (iv) | {{convert|177|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|1102|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2007 | Built from 1949 and 1952 by more than 60 architects, the buildings, open spaces and sports facilities combine modern architecture with references to local pre-Hispanic traditions. They showcase universal ideals such as access to education and improvement in the quality of life that were prevalent in post-[[Mexican Revolution|revolutionary]] Mexico. |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1250|title=Central University City Campus of the ''Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México'' (UNAM)|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Chaco Culture]] | [[File:Chaco Canyon Chetro Ketl great kiva plaza NPS.jpg|150x150px|alt=Ruins of a circular and rectangular buildings made of stones.]] | United States[[New Mexico]],
{{flag|United States}}
{{coord|36|3|50|N|107|58|15|W|type:landmark|name=Chaco Culture}} | Cultural:
(iii) | align="center" | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" |1987 | Notable for its monumental buildings, the site bears testimony to a [[Pueblo]] culture that dominated large parts of present-day south-western United States from the mid-9th to early 13th centuries. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/353|title=Chaco Culture|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Dinosaur Provincial Park]] | [[File:Chasmosaurus belli RTM 01.jpg|150x150px|alt=A skeleton of a dinosaur.]] | Canada[[Alberta]],
{{flag|Canada}}
{{coord|50|46|4|N|111|29|32|W|type:landmark|name=Dinosaur Provincial Park}} | Natural:
(vii), (viii) | {{convert|7493|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" |1979 | The park is noted for the beauty of its [[badland]] landscape and as a major fossil site. Specimens of every group of [[cretaceous]] dinosaurs have been found here including those of 35 species dating more than 75 Million years ago. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/71|title=Dinosaur Provincial Park|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|popocatepetl|[[Monasteries on the slopes of Popocatépetl|Earliest 16th-century Monasteries on the Slopes of Popocatepetl]]}} | [[File:001 Convento de Huejotzingo. Puerta de la Porciúncula. ManuelParadaLopezdeCorselas.jpg|center|150x150px|alt=Front of a church with two towers. The portal around the door is decorated with reliefs of two angels, Maria and two other figures.]] | {{sort|Mexico|[[Morelos]] and [[Puebla]], {{flag|Mexico}}
{{coord|18|56|N|98|54|W|name=Earliest 16th-Century Monasteries on the Slopes of Popocatepetl}}}} | Cultural:
(ii), (iv) | align="center" | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" | 1994 | The site comprises 14 monasteries built by [[Augustinian]]s, [[Franciscans]] and [[Dominican Order|Dominicans]] near [[Popocatépetl]] volcano. Stylistically they are characterized by an emphasize on open spaces, a concept that influenced architecture in Mexico and beyond. |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/702|title=Earliest 16th-Century Monasteries on the Slopes of Popocatepetl|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|Pinacate|[[El Pinacate y Gran Desierto de Altar Biosphere Reserve|El Pinacate and Gran Desierto de Altar Biosphere Reserve]]}} | [[File:Pinacate volcanic field.jpg|150x150px|alt=Crater Elegante with the Pinacate peaks.]] | {{sort|Mexico|[[Sonora]], {{flag|Mexico}}
{{coord|32|00|00|N|113|55|00|W|name=El Pinacate and Gran Desierto de Altar Biosphere Reserve}}}} | Natural:
(vii), (viii), (x) | {{convert|714566|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|354871|ha|abbr=values}}; | align="center" | 2013 | The 714,566-hectare site comprises two distinct parts: the dormant volcanic [[Pinacate Peaks|Pinacate]] Shield of black and red lava flows and desert pavements to the east, and, in the west, the [[Gran Desierto de Altar|Gran Altar Desert]] with its ever-changing and varied sand dunes that can reach a height of 200 metres. This landscape of dramatic contrast notably features linear, star and dome dunes as well as several arid granite massifs, some as high as 650 metres. |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1410|title=El Pinacate and Gran Desierto de Altar Biosphere Reserve|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=25 June 2013}} |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|tajin|Prehistoric city of [[El Tajín]]}} | [[File:El Tajín, Nischenpyramide.fcm.jpg|150x150px|alt=Ruins of a stone pyramid with about five levels. Each side of a step contains niches.]] | {{sort|Mexico|[[Veracruz]], {{flag|Mexico}}
{{coord|20|28|35|N|97|22|39|W|name=El Tajin, Pre-Hispanic City}}}} | Cultural:
(iii), (iv) | align="center" | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" | 1992 | Flourishing from the early 9th to early 13th century, El Tajin is the prime site of the period between the [[Teotihuacan]] and [[Tenochtitlan]] empires. |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/631|title=El Tajin, Pre-Hispanic City|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}} |-style="background-color: #FFE6BD" ! scope="row" style="background-color: #FFE6BD"| [[Everglades National Park]]† | [[File:Gfp-florida-everglades-national-park-pine-forest.jpg|150x150px|alt=A large white bird with black wingtips and a long slightly curved beak is perched on a branch above grassland.]] | United States[[Florida]],
{{flag|United States}}
{{coord|25|19|N|80|56|W|region:US_type:landmark|name=Everglades National Park}} | Natural:
(viii), (ix), (x) | {{convert|592920|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" |1979 | The vast wetlands and coastal/marine habitats of the park have made it a sanctuary for many animals including 20 rare, endangered and threatened species such as the [[Florida panther]] and the [[manatee]]. The site has been [[World Heritage in Danger|endangered]] from 1993–2007 following damage due to [[Hurricane Andrew]] and since 2010 due to continued degradation and a loss of marine habitat. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/76 |title=Everglades National Park |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}}
{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/1993/whc-93-conf002-14e.pdf |title=World Heritage Committee: Seventeenth session |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011|pages=20–21}}
{{harvnb|34th session|2010|pp=82–83}} |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|Querétaro|[[Franciscan Missions in the Sierra Gorda|Franciscan Missions in the Sierra Gorda of Querétaro]]}} | [[File:MissionTanyocol2.JPG|center|150x150px|alt=Facade of a church with one tower. The name of the site was changed accordingly from ''Wrangell/St. Elias/Kluane'' at the time of inscription to ''Glacier Bay/Wrangell/St. Elias/Kluane'' in 1992 to the present name in 1994. | These parks comprise the world's largest non-polar icefield, some of the largest glaciers and a tectonically active mountain landscape. They are home to a number of species endangered elsewhere such as bears, wolves, [[caribou]] and [[Dall sheep]]. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/72|title=Kluane / Wrangell-St Elias / Glacier Bay / Tatshenshini-Alsek|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}}

{{flag|Kingdom of Denmark}}
{{coord|61|9|52|N|45|35|52|W|type:landmark_region:DK|name=Kujataa: Norse and Inuit Farming at the Edge of the Ice Cap}}}} | Cultural:
(v) | {{convert|34892|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" |2017 | Kujataa is a subarctic farming landscape located in the southern region of Greenland. It bears witness to the cultural histories of the Norse farmer-hunters who started arriving from Iceland in the 10th century and of the Inuit hunters and Inuit farming communities that developed from the end of the 18th century. Despite their differences, the two cultures, European Norse and Inuit, created a cultural landscape based on farming, grazing and marine mammal hunting. The landscape represents the earliest introduction of farming to the Arctic, and the Norse expansion of settlement beyond Europe. | {{cite web |url=https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1536|title=Kujataa Greenland: Norse and Inuit Farming at the Edge of the Ice Cap|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=21 November 2018}} [[File:CC-BY-SA icon.svg|50px]] This article contains quotations from this source, which is available under the[https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/igo/legalcode Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 IGO] license.

{{coord|37|15|42|N|108|29|8|W|type:landmark|name=Mesa Verde National Park}} | Cultural:
(iii) | align="center" | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" |1978 | Protects some of the best preserved [[Ancestral Puebloans|Ancestral Puebloan]] archaeological sites in the U.S. Starting circa 7500 BC, Mesa Verde was seasonally inhabited by a group of nomadic [[Paleo-Indians]] known as the Foothills Mountain Complex. The variety of projectile points found in the region indicates they were influenced by surrounding areas, including the [[Great Basin]], the [[San Juan Basin]], and the [[Rio Grande Valley]]. Later, [[Archaic period in North America|Archaic]] people established semi-permanent rockshelters in and around the [[mesa]]. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/27|title=Mesa Verde National Park|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Miguasha National Park]] | [[File:Miguasha panorama 1.jpg|150x150px|alt=Forested mountains with rocks and pebble beach.]] | Canada[[Gaspé Peninsula]], [[Quebec]]
{{flag|Canada}}
{{coord|48|6|18|N|66|21|11|W|type:landmark|name=Miguasha National Park}} | Natural:
(viii) | {{convert|87|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" |1999 | Protects thousands of fossils in eastern Quebec that are 350 to 375 million years old. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/686|title=Miguasha National Park|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Mistaken Point Ecological Reserve|Mistaken Point]] | [[File:Ediacaran fossils Mistaken Point Newfoundland.jpg|150x150px|alt=An Ediacaran fossil found at Mistaken Point.]] | Canada[[Newfoundland and Labrador]]
{{flag|Canada}}
{{coord|46|37|55|N|53|11|25|W|type:landmark|name=Mistaken Point}} | Natural:
(viii) | {{convert|146|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" |2016 | Area around the [[Mistaken Point Formation]]: protection of [[Ediacaran]] [[fossils]] representing the oldest [[multicellular life]] on Earth. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1497|title=Mistaken Point|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=18 July 2016}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve]] | [[File:Mexmonarchs.jpg|150x150px|alt=A large number of orange butterflies in flight.]] | {{sort|Mexico|[[Michoacán]] and [[Mexico State]], {{flag|Mexico}}
{{coord|19|36|23|N|100|14|30|W|name=Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve}}}} | Natural:
(vii) | {{convert|13552|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|42707|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2008 | Site containing most of the over-wintering sites of the eastern population of the [[monarch butterfly]]. The reserve is located in the [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt pine-oak forests]] [[ecoregion]] on the border of [[Michoacán]] and [[State of Mexico]], 100 km (62 miles), northwest of [[Mexico City]]. |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1290|title=Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Monticello]] and the [[University of Virginia]] in [[Charlottesville, Virginia|Charlottesville]] | [[File:Monticello 2010-10-29.jpg|150x150px|alt=Red brick building with a white classicist columned entrance.]] | United States[[Virginia]],
{{flag|United States}}
{{coord|38|1|58|N|78|30|14|W|type:landmark|name=Monticello and the University of Virginia in Charlottesville}} | Cultural:
(i), (iv), (vi) | align="center" | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" |1987 | Built between 1769 and 1809, Monticello was the plantation home of its designer, third [[President of the United States]] and author of the [[United States Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]], [[Thomas Jefferson]]. Jefferson designed the early buildings that made up the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, inspired by his new ideas of university planning. The most prominent of these, [[The Rotunda (University of Virginia)|The Rotunda]], is a half-scale model of the [[Pantheon, Rome|Pantheon]] in [[Rome]]. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/442|title=Monticello and the University of Virginia in Charlottesville|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Pimachiowin Aki]] | [[File:Woodland_Caribou_Provincial_Park.jpg|150x150px|alt=Rock wall at Woodland Caribou Provincial Park.]] | {{sort|Canada|[[Manitoba]] and [[Ontario]], {{flag|Canada}}
{{coord|51|49|0|N|95|24|0|W|name=Pimachiowin Aki}}}} | Cultural:
(iii), (vi), (ix) | align="center" | {{convert|2,904,000|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|3,592,000|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2018 | |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1415|title=Pimachiowin Aki|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=1 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Poverty Point|Monumental Earthworks of Poverty Point]] | [[File:Poverty Point World Heritage Site.jpg|150px]] | United States[[Louisiana]],
{{flag|United States}}
{{coord|32|38|13|N|91|24|23|W|type:landmark|name=Monumental Earthworks of Poverty Point}} | Cultural:
(iii) | {{convert|163|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" |2014 | Comprises several earthworks and [[mound]]s, built between 1650 and 700 [[Anno Domini|BC]] during the [[archaic period in North America]], by a group of [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]]s of the Poverty Point culture. The culture extended {{convert|100|mi|km}} across the [[Mississippi Delta]]. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1435 |title=Monumental Earthworks of Poverty Point |accessdate=June 23, 2014 |publisher=UNESCO}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Nahanni National Park]] | [[File:Nahanni - VirginiaFalls.jpg|150x150px|alt=Large but relatively low waterfall through rocks.]] | Canada[[Northwest Territories]]
{{flag|Canada}}
{{coord|61|33|N|125|35|W|type:landmark|name=Nahanni National Park}} | Natural:

{{flag|Canada}}

(iv), (v) | align="center" | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" |1995 | The town was one of the first British attempts to settle Protestants in Nova Scotia intended to displace Mi'kmaq and Acadian Catholics. It was founded during [[Father Le Loutre's War]] on [[Mahone Bay]]. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/741|title=Old Town Lunenburg|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Olympic National Park]] | [[File:Cool Clear Water.jpg|150x150px|alt=Rocky coastline with trees on the top of the rocks.]] | United States[[Washington (state)|Washington]],
{{flag|United States}}
{{coord|47|45|N|123|27|W|type:landmark|name=Olympic National Park}} | Natural:
(vii), (ix) | {{convert|369660|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" |1981 | Located on the [[Olympic Peninsula]], the park has four basic regions: the Pacific coastline, alpine areas, the west side temperate rainforest and the forests of the drier east side. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/151|title=Olympic National Park|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|palenque|[[Pre-Hispanic City and National Park of Palenque]]}} | [[File:Palenque Ruins.jpg|150x150px|alt=Ruins and walls of structures. A four storied square tower is in relatively good condition. The site is surrounded by forest.]] | {{sort|Mexico|[[Chiapas]], {{flag|Mexico}}

At the top of the pyramid there is a square structure with flat roof and entrances from both visible sides.]] | {{sort|Mexico|[[Yucatán (state)|Yucatán]], {{flag|Mexico}}

{{coord|45|0|N|75|46|W|type:landmark|name=Rideau Canal}} | Cultural:
(i), (iv) | {{convert|21455|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|2363|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" |2007 |The Rideau Canal (French: ''Canal Rideau'') connects [[Ottawa]] to [[Lake Ontario]] and the [[Saint Lawrence River]]. It was opened in 1832 as a precaution in case of war with the United States and is still in use today, with most of its original structures intact. The canal system uses sections of major rivers, including the [[Rideau River|Rideau]] and the [[Cataraqui River|Cataraqui]], as well as some lakes. It is the oldest continuously operated canal system in North America. | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1221|title=Rideau Canal|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|sierra de san francisco|[[Rock Paintings of the Sierra de San Francisco]]}} | [[File:Baja California Sur.jpg|150x150px|The Rock Paintings of Sierra de San Francisco|alt=Prehistoric rock art pictographs of the Cochimi in the Sierra de San Francisco mountain range.]] | {{sort|Mexico|[[Baja California Sur]], {{flag|Mexico}}
{{coord|27|39|20|N|112|54|58|W|name=Rock Paintings of the Sierra de San Francisco}}}} | Cultural:
(i), (iii) | align="center" | {{ntsh|0}}— | align="center" | 1993 | |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/714|title=Rock Paintings of the Sierra de San Francisco|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[San Antonio Missions (World Heritage Site)|San Antonio Missions]] | [[File:Mission Espada Chapel1.JPG|150x150px|alt=Stone church building with a tiered belltower]] | United States[[Texas]],

{{flag|Canada}}
{{coord|59|22|N|112|18|W|type:landmark|name=Wood Buffalo National Park}} | Natural:
(vii), (ix), (x) | {{convert|4480000|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" |1983 | | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/256|title=Wood Buffalo National Park|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Yellowstone National Park]] | {{center|[[File:Yellowstone Lower Fall.jpg|150x150px|alt=Large waterfall in a rocky mountain landscape.]]}} | {{sort|United States|[[Wyoming]], [[Montana]], and [[Idaho]], {{flag|United States}}
{{coord|44|30|N|110|50|W|name=Yellowstone National Park}}}} | Natural:
(vii), (viii), (ix), (x) | {{convert|898349|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1978 | [[World Heritage in Danger|Endangered]] from 1995 to 2003. Yellowstone Park is the largest and most famous [[megafauna]] location in the [[contiguous United States]]. [[Grizzly bear]]s, [[gray wolf|wolves]], and free-ranging herds of [[American bison|bison]] and [[elk]] live in the park. The [[Yellowstone Park bison herd]] is the oldest and largest public bison herd in the United States. [[Old Faithful]] and [[Grand Prismatic Spring]] are two of the park's most famous sites. |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/28|title=Yellowstone National Park|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Yosemite National Park]] | {{center|[[File:Tunnel View 2, Yosemite Valley, Yosemite NP - Diliff.jpg|150x150px|alt=Forested valley lined by large rocks.]]}} | {{sort|United States|[[California]], {{flag|United States}}
{{coord|37|45|N|119|36|W|name=Yosemite National Park}}}} | Natural:
(vii), (viii) | {{convert|308283|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1984 | Yosemite is one of the largest and least fragmented habitat blocks in the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]]. The park supports a diversity of plants and animals and has an elevation range from {{convert|2127|to|13114|ft|m}}. It contains five major [[life zone|vegetation zones]]: [[chaparral]] and [[oak]] woodland, [[Sierra Nevada lower montane forest|lower montane forest]], upper [[montane forest]], [[Sierra Nevada subalpine zone|subalpine zone]], and [[Alpine tundra|alpine]]. Of California's 7,000 plant species, about 50% occur in the Sierra Nevada and more than 20% within Yosemite. There is suitable habitat for more than 160 rare plants in the park, with rare local [[geology|geologic]] formations and unique [[soil]]s characterizing the restricted ranges many of these plants occupy. |{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/308|title=Yosemite National Park|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}} |} ==See also== *[[Lists of World Heritage Sites]] ==Notes== {{Infobox writer | name = Michael B. Druxman | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1941|02|23}} | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|1941|02|23}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = [[Screenwriter]], [[novelist]] | language = English | nationality = United States | education = | alma_mater = | website = {{URL|www.druxmanworks.com/home.html}} }} '''Michael B. Druxman''' (born February 23, 1941) is a screenwriter, active primarily in the 1990s. His scripts for [[B-movie]] producer [[Roger Corman]] include ''[[Cheyenne Warrior]]'' (1994) with [[Kelly Preston]], ''Dillinger and Capone'' (1995) starring [[Martin Sheen]] and [[F. Murray Abraham]] and ''The Doorway'' (2000) with [[Roy Scheider]], which he also directed.<ref>http://www.austin360.com/movies/hollywood-veteran-michael-b-druxman-winds-up-adjusting-1246089.html</ref><ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20100914035926/http://bearmanormedia.bizland.com/id528.html</ref><ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20081204072914/http://www.screenwritersutopia.com/modules.php?name=Content&pa=showpage&pid=59</ref>
Druxman is also the author of one-person plays, ''Lombard'' and ''Jolson.''
Additionally, he is the author several [[non-fiction]] works about Hollywood, its movies and the people who make them, including ''Basil Rathbone: His Life and His Films'', ''The Art of Storytelling: How To Write A Story... Any Story'', ''Make It Again, Sam: A Survey of Movie Remakes'', ''Miss Dinah Shore'', plus the novels, ''Nobody Drowns in Mineral Lake'', ''Shadow Watcher'', ''Murder in Babylon'', ''Jackie Goes to Dixie'', and ''Dark Chasm''.
His memoirs, ''My Forty-Five Years in Hollywood and How I Escaped Alive'', were published in August 2010, by Bear Manor Media.
